edu.nyu.cs.javagit.api

Class JavaGitConfiguration

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.nyu.cs.javagit.api.JavaGitConfiguration

  • public final class JavaGitConfiguration
extends java.lang.Object
    This class encapsulates our global API options that client code may want to get or set. TODO (rs2705): Create a more generalized/modularized setup where variables and methods related to specific implementation types are self-contained in their own separate classes, instead of floating around in here.

    • Method Detail

      • getGitCommand

        public static java.lang.String getGitCommand()
        Return the complete string necessary to invoke git on the command line. Could be an absolute path to git, or if the path was never set explicitly, just "git".
        Returns:
        String containing the path to git, ending with the git executable's name itself.

      • getGitCommandPrefix

        public static java.lang.String getGitCommandPrefix()
        Return an absolute path capable of being dropped in front of the command-line git invocation. If the path hasn't been set explicitly, just return the empty string and assume git is in this process' PATH environment variable.
        Returns:
        The String that points to the git executable.

      • getGitPath

        public static java.io.File getGitPath()
        Accessor method for the File object representing the path to git. If the git path is never set explicitly, this will return null.
        Returns:
        File object pointing at the directory containing git.

      • getGitVersion

        public static java.lang.String getGitVersion()
                                      throws JavaGitException
        Returns the version number of the underlying git binaries. If this method is called and we don't know the version yet, it tries to figure it out. (The version gets set if setGitPath was previously called.)
        Returns:
        The git version String.
        Throws:
        JavaGitException

      • getGitVersionObject

        public static GitVersion getGitVersionObject()
                                      throws JavaGitException
        Throws:
        JavaGitException

      • setGitPath

        public static void setGitPath(java.io.File path)
                       throws java.io.IOException,
                              JavaGitException
        Called when client code wants to explicitly tell us where to find git on their filesystem. If never called, we assume that git is in a directory in the PATH environment variable for this process. Passing null as the path argument will unset an explicitly-set path and revert to looking for git in the PATH.
        Parameters:
        path - File object representing the directory containing the git binaries. It must contain either an absolute path, or a valid path relative to the current working directory.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Thrown if the provided path does not exist.
        JavaGitException - Thrown if git does not exist at the provided path, or the provided path is not a directory.

      • setGitPath

        public static void setGitPath(java.lang.String path)
                       throws java.io.IOException,
                              JavaGitException
        Convenience method for setting the path with a String instead of a File. TODO (rs2705): Enforce the requirement below that the path be absolute. Is there a simple way to do this in an OS-independent fashion?
        Parameters:
        path - Absolute path to git binaries installed on the system. The path must be absolute since it needs to persist for the life of the client code, even if the working directory changes. Throws a NullPointerException if path is null, or an IllegalArgumentException if it's the empty string.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Thrown if the provided path does not exist.
        JavaGitException - Thrown if we cannot find git at the path provided.
